metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: A constructor is a special method that is automatically called when an object of a class is created.
content.html: A constructor is a special method that is automatically called when an object of a class is created.

content.text: To create a constructor, use the same name as the class, followed by parentheses () :
content.html: To create a constructor, use the same name as the class, followed by parentheses ():

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Create an object of MyClass (this will call 
  the constructor)

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Create an object of MyClass (this will call 
  the constructor)

content.code_html:
class MyClass {     // The class
  public:           // Access specifier
    MyClass() {     // Constructor
      cout << "Hello World!";
    }
};

int main() {
  MyClass myObj;    // Create an object of MyClass (this will call the constructor)
  return 0;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Create an object of MyClass (this will call 
  the constructor)

content.text: Constructors can also take parameters (just like regular functions), which can be useful for setting initial values for attributes.
content.html: Constructors can also take parameters (just like regular functions), which can be useful for setting initial values for attributes.

content.text: The following class have brand , model and year attributes, and a constructor with different parameters. Inside the constructor we set the attributes equal to the constructor parameters ( brand=x , etc).
content.html: The following class have brand, model and year attributes, and a constructor with different parameters. Inside the constructor we set the attributes equal to the constructor parameters (brand=x, etc).

content.text: When we call the constructor (by creating an object of the class), we pass parameters to the constructor, which will set the value of the corresponding attributes to the same:
content.html: When we call the constructor (by creating an object of the class), we pass parameters to the constructor, which will set the value of the corresponding attributes to the same:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
class Car {        // The class  public:          // Access specifier    
    string brand;  // Attribute    string model;  // Attribute    
    int year;      // Attribute    
    Car(string x, string y, int z) 
    { // Constructor with parameters      brand = 
    x;      model = y;      
    year = z;    }};int main() {  // 
    Create Car objects and call the constructor with different values  
    Car carObj1("BMW", "X5", 1999);  Car carObj2("Ford", "Mustang", 
    1969);  // Print values  cout << carObj1.brand << " " 
    << carObj1.model << " " << carObj1.year << "\n";  cout << 
    carObj2.brand << " " << carObj2.model << " " << carObj2.year << "\n";  
    return 0;}

// 
    Create Car objects and call the constructor with different values

content.code:
class Car {        // The class  public:          // Access specifier
string brand;  // Attribute    string model;  // Attribute
int year;      // Attribute
Car(string x, string y, int z)
{ // Constructor with parameters      brand =
x;      model = y;
year = z;    }};int main() {  //
Create Car objects and call the constructor with different values
Car carObj1("BMW", "X5", 1999);  Car carObj2("Ford", "Mustang",
1969);  // Print values  cout << carObj1.brand << " "
<< carObj1.model << " " << carObj1.year << "\n";  cout <<
carObj2.brand << " " << carObj2.model << " " << carObj2.year << "\n";
return 0;}

syntax_highlighting.text:
class Car {        // The class  public:          // Access specifier    
    string brand;  // Attribute    string model;  // Attribute    
 int year;      // Attribute    
 Car(string x, string y, int z) 
    { // Constructor with parameters      brand = 
    x;      model = y;      
    year = z;    }};int main() {  // 
    Create Car objects and call the constructor with different values  
    Car carObj1("BMW", "X5", 1999);  Car carObj2("Ford", "Mustang", 
 1969);  // Print values  cout << carObj1.brand << " " 
    << carObj1.model << " " << carObj1.year << "\n";  cout << 
    carObj2.brand << " " << carObj2.model << " " << carObj2.year << "\n";  
 return 0;}

// 
    Create Car objects and call the constructor with different values

content.code_html:
class Car {        // The class
  public:          // Access specifier
    string brand;  // Attribute
    string model;  // Attribute
    int year;      // Attribute
    Car(string x, string y, int z) { // Constructor with parameters
      brand = x;
      model = y;
      year = z;
    }
};

int main() {
  // Create Car objects and call the constructor with different values
  Car carObj1("BMW", "X5", 1999);
  Car carObj2("Ford", "Mustang", 1969);

  // Print values
  cout << carObj1.brand << " " << carObj1.model << " " << carObj1.year << "\n";
  cout << carObj2.brand << " " << carObj2.model << " " << carObj2.year << "\n";
  return 0;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
class Car {        // The class  public:          // Access specifier    
    string brand;  // Attribute    string model;  // Attribute    
    int year;      // Attribute    
    Car(string x, string y, int z) 
    { // Constructor with parameters      brand = 
    x;      model = y;      
    year = z;    }};int main() {  // 
    Create Car objects and call the constructor with different values  
    Car carObj1("BMW", "X5", 1999);  Car carObj2("Ford", "Mustang", 
    1969);  // Print values  cout << carObj1.brand << " " 
    << carObj1.model << " " << carObj1.year << "\n";  cout << 
    carObj2.brand << " " << carObj2.model << " " << carObj2.year << "\n";  
    return 0;}

// 
    Create Car objects and call the constructor with different values

content.text: You can also define the constructor outside the class using the scope resolution operator :: .
content.html: You can also define the constructor outside the class using the scope resolution operator ::.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Create 
    Car objects and call the constructor with different values

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Create 
    Car objects and call the constructor with different values

content.code_html:
class Car {        // The class
  public:          // Access specifier
    string brand;  // Attribute
    string model;  // Attribute
    int year;      // Attribute
    Car(string x, string y, int z); // Constructor declaration
};

// Constructor definition outside the class
Car::Car(string x, string y, int z) {
  brand = x;
  model = y;
  year = z;
}

int main() {
  // Create Car objects and call the constructor with different values
  Car carObj1("BMW", "X5", 1999);
  Car carObj2("Ford", "Mustang", 1969);

  // Print values
  cout << carObj1.brand << " " << carObj1.model << " " << carObj1.year << "\n";
  cout << carObj2.brand << " " << carObj2.model << " " << carObj2.year << "\n";
  return 0;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Create 
    Car objects and call the constructor with different values

content.text: Constructors run by themselves when you create an object. They set things up so everything is ready right away.
content.html: Constructors run by themselves when you create an object. They set things up so everything is ready right away.

content.text: Think of it like this: When you order a pizza (object), the constructor is the chef who adds the sauce, cheese, and toppings before it gets to you - you don't have to do it yourself!
content.html: Think of it like this: When you order a pizza (object), the constructor is the chef who adds the sauce, cheese, and toppings before it gets to you - you don't have to do it yourself!

content.html: How do you define a constructor in C++?

metadata.question: How do you define a constructor in C++?

options.text: By defining a function with the keyword 'constructor'
Using the class name followed by parentheses

content.question: How do you define a constructor in C++?

options.text: By defining a function with the keyword 'constructor'
Using the class name followed by parentheses
